(202) 473-1000 INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELC M o D.C. 20433 Cable Address: INTBAFRAD INTERNATIONAL DE\E LOPMENT ASSOCIATION xn 0 DC 20433 Cable Address: INDEVAS November 8, 2012 Mr. Luc Frieden Min-ster of Finance L-2391 Luxembourg Amendment to the Atministration Agreement between the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Interniational Development Association concerning the Road to Europe Program for Accounting and Institutional Strengthening (REPARIS) MAulti-Donor Trust Fund (TFO71151) Dezr Mr. Frieden: 1. We refer to the Administration Agreement between the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg (the "Donor") md the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and the International Development Association (IDA), (collectively, the "Bank") rega -ding the Road to Europe Program for Accounting and Institutional Strengthening (REPARIS) Multi-Donor Trust Fund (TFO71151) (the "Trust Fund") effective January 19, 2009, as amended (the "Administration Agreement"). 2. Pursuant to recent disc ussions between the Bank and the Donor, the Bank pro:oses amendments to the Ad ministration Agreement as set forth below: Paragraph 2 of the Agreement is hereby amended to read as follows: "2. The Contribution shall be used to finance the activities and the categories of expendituwe set forth in the "Description of Activities under the REPARIS Multi-Donoi Trust Fund" attached hereto as Annex 1, which constitutes an integral part of this Agreement. The activities for the Trust Fund shall be further detailed in the work plan of the Program, including for the period from October 2, 2008 to April 30, 2018." Annex 1 of the Agreement is replaced in its entirety by a new Annex 1 "Description of Activities under the REPARIS Multi-Donor Trust Fund" attached to this Amendment Letter. RCA 248423. W WUI 64145 L FAX (202) 477-6391
ï»¿-2- Paragraph 7.1 of Annex 2 of the Agreement is hereby modified to read as follows: "7.1 The Ba-ik shall piovide the Donors with annual progress reports on Bank- executed activities and semi-annual status updates on Recipient-executed activities financed by ihe Contributions. Within six (6) months of the final disbursement date specif ied in paragraph 8.1. the Bank shall furnish to the Donors a final report on the activities financed by the Trust Fund." Paragraph 8.1 of Annex 2 of the Agreement is hereby modified to read as follows: "8.1 It is expected tha. the Contributions will be fully disbursed by the Bank by April 30, 2018. The Bank shall only disburse Contributions for the purposes of this Agreemert after suc i dale with the written approval of the Donors." 3. All other terms of the Ac ministration Agreement shall remain the same. 4 The Bank will disclose this Amendment and related information on this Trust Fund in accordance with the World Bank Policy on Access to Information. By entering into this Agreement, the Donor consents to disclosure of this Agreement and related infcnation on this Trust Fund. 5. We propose that this letter shall constitute an amendment to the Administration Agreement between the Bank and the Donor. Please confirm your acceptance to the foregoing, on behalf of the Donor, by signing and dating the two originals, retaining one original for your reccrds and returnIng the other original to the Bank. Upon receipt by the Bank of the original Amendment countersigned by you, this Amendment will become effective as of the date of the cointersignature. Sincerely, INTERNATIONAL BANK OR. RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION Gerard A.* By Director \ Op.rational Services & Quality Europe and Central Asia Region

ï»¿-4- ANNEX I Description of Acti.vities and Expenditures under the REPARIS Multi-Donor Trust Fund This Annex slall be ap)licable to and forms an integral part of all agreements ente:-ed into between the BanI. and entities (collectively, the "Donors") that provide cowributions (the aggregate ofitll contributions from the Donors, the "Contributions") to be administered by th,-, Bank for the Trust Fund. A. Definitions Unless the context requircs otherwise, the capitalized terms used in this Agf eement have the f )llowing n iean ings: (a) "CAP" means Country Action Plan document prepared by a country with a detailed acticn Flan for financial reporting reforms and related institutional capa-ity development activities within the country. (b) "CFRIZ" means Centre for Financial Reporting Reform, a unit established by the Bank in V enna, inter alia, to serve as the REPARIS secretariat. (c) "CoP" means a Community of Practice; a community of stakeholders comprised of po icy makers, academia, and professional accounting and auditing bodies ftom --.he Beneficiary Countries. (d) "MPG" means Market Participants Group which comprises representatives (f private sector financial institutions, enterprises and organizations wiich have pan-regional insights and perspectives on financial reporting in practice in the CFRR's partner countries. These include, for exar.-iple, banking groups with branches and subsidiaries in partnei countries, in:3titutional and real sector foreign investors in the region, internaticnal and regional bodies of accountancy associations and firms, and similar entAies. (e) "Beneficiary Co intries" includes Albania, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bosnia and Her. egovina, Croatia, FYR Macedonia, Georgia, Kosovo, Moldova, Montenegro, Serbia, and Ukraine. "Regicn" means Europe and Central Asia Region. (g) "RLG" means Reg,ilatory Liaison Group chaired by the European Commission which cc)mprises representatives of European Union ("EU") and inlernational regulatory and standard-setting bodies which play a key role in the determinadon and enforcement of best practice in the field of corporate sector financial reporting.
ï»¿-5- B. Background and Objectives High quality fInancial reporting makes a direct contribution to improving the lives of people and reducing poverty. As a result of the timely provision of reliable information about the financial position and performance of enterprises, enhanced confidence is brought to the relationship betw%een enterprises (in both the real and the financial sectors, including state owned enterprise s) and their stakeholders. This facilitates improved levels of overnance and transparency, fosters the development of an enabling business environment and investment cli:nate, and underpins more effective relationships between the corporate sector and the state. In turn, these developments support enhanced mobilization of domestic and foreign savings, improved access to credit, higher levels of priN ate-sector-led growth, and the development of financial and capital markets. Economic growth, combined with equity, is a key contributor to improving people's lives and the fight against poverty. As has been reconfirmed in recent years by the financial crisis, inadequacies in financia. reporting increase the risk of financial instability, the consequences of which are fe t disproportionately by the poor, so improvements in financial reporting are an essertial element of any public policy response to the crisis. Finally, as issues relating to financial reporting form an important element of the European Union's body of law, the acquis communautaire, improvements in this field are of major importance to both (ounries seeking EU membership as well as countries seeking closer relations and inte gration with the EU. The objective of the Rc ad to Europe Program for Accounting and Institutional Strengthening Multi.-Donor Trust Fund ("REPARIS MDTF") is to support the implementation of bcth regional anJ country-specific activities with a view to tackling issues shared by Beneficiary Countries, to promote cooperation among them, and to ensure coordinated actions with.n a common framework, while facilitating financing and implementation support to the cointries in their endeavors to implement financial reporting reforms at tie nationa level as set out in their respective CAPs. The REPARIS METF aims to achieve the following results: (a) updated regulatory frameworks for corporate financial reporting within the countries, that achieve greater degrees of alignment with the relevant EC acquis communautaire, and that are proportional to the country's integration with the EU. - (b) an increase in Icng term partnerships with, or memberships of, relevant EU ard/or globil peer organizations to achieve sustainability of the accourting educ itior. reforms; an increase in the number of countries implementing o - algning themselves with the EU Statutory Audit Directive auditor education requirements; and an increase in the number of studen:s who are provided with the opportunity to access modern updated undergraduate ac-ourting and auditing education courses. (c) availability of updated and translated standards in the languages of the Benefi-iary Countries; financial reporting and statutory audit (and public .oversight) arrangements that are better aligned with the requirements of the EC acquis communautaire; a technical support system that will enable
ï»¿-6- more effective i:nplementing and enforcement arrangements throughout the Region; ard more effective regulation of financial reporting requircments by ])rudential supervisors. (d) performance maniagement system for corporate financial reporting reform activities and a web-based portal containing a repository of information provid.ng advice, tools, and methodologies to support ongoing implementation cf the relevant acquis. The REPARIS MDTF ond its activities provide a framework to ensure a strong integration of assessment, advis ry, financial, operational, and monitoring and evaluation (M&E) support to achieve alignment with the requirements of the acquis communautaire in the field of corporate reporting, ard seeks to: (a) help Beneficiary Countries establish strong institutional and regulatory frameworks necessary for increased transparency, for effective functioning of the internal market and for mitigation of the risks of financial system crises; and (b) assist In institutional, regulatory and accounting capacity development, alongs: de the EU, other development partners, and private and public sector stakeholdcrs, to improve the business environment and investment climate and to failitate Beneficiary Countries' alignment with the EU and the EU internal market. C. Description of Activities (a) Bank- Executed rrust Fund Activities: (i) Reform Momentum and Regional Cooperation. Reinforce the accounting and audit reform momentum and regional cooperation by organ zing a series of videoconferences and hold high-level ministerizl conferences on a regular basis for Beneficiary Countries and other senior officials to provide the ongoing strategic validation of progress made; presenting the latest developments in financial reporting regulation; and providing the private sector, including foreign direct investors, an opportunity to provide feedback on the issues they face. Expected outputs include a series of videoconferences, high-level ministerizl conferences; associated technical workshops; EU level/international discussions; advice on best practices; periodic meetings of senior officials; and regular information sharing on new developments, experiences of the participants in reform implemer taticn, and challenges ahead. (ii) Curricula Development and Education Reform in Accounting and Auditing. Facilitate efforts to reform and upgrade
ï»¿-7- accounting elucation systems by focusing on the common challenge3 faced by universities, professional accounting bodies, chambers of auditors, and regulators. There is a substantial commonality of curriculum content, qualification systems and lifelong learning requirements that can be applied throughout the countries of the Region to support the relevant stakeholder institutior.s. The implementation of International Accounting Educatior Standards, application of the education requirements of the EU Statutory Audit Directive, and identification and replication of the e> periences of developed EU universities in accounting education are amongst the aims which have been set by the Accounting Education CoP. The CFRR will work with the CoP on the development of identified common approaches and solutions to the shared challenges, as well as facilitate collaboration with EU and relevant global peer institutions and bodies. Expected outputs include a series of regular videoconferences utilizing tae World Bank's Global Development Learning Network (GDLN) and CoP workshops. The CFRR will provide technical assistance to the CoP to facilitate the development of an e-based information and resources portal that will allow universities, professional bodies and regulators to access educational resources and tool; to support their development and implementation activities. The CFRR will work to increase the capacity CoP participant institutions to engage with their EU and global peers, such as the International Federation of Accountants, the Federation of Europe an Accountants, the International Forum of Independent Audit RegulatDrs, and EU universities. (iii) Moving J'ormard in Accounting and Auditing. Provide technical assistance to the work of the CoP(s) and/or Practice Forum(s) that are form,A to address regional challenges. The key thematic challenge, on which the CFRR will provide technical support through the CoP(s) include addressing the financial reporting needs of Small anc Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs), defining the scope of pplication of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), 1he enforcement of financial reporting requirements, improving the quality of audits through the introduction of quality assurance systems, and the introduction of public oversight arrangem,mts for the statutory audit function. The Region faces the challenge of providing access to updated translated versions of internatio ial standards, and shortages of highly skilled and experienced professionals to implement and enforce these. Work under th s component will be coordinated with that of the Accounting Education CoP to identify and facilitate the development of sharable solutions to these needs through continuoL s professional education. The CFRR will also continue
ï»¿-8- the regio ial training program on the use of IFRS by financial sector reg ulators and supervisors, through facilitating a thorough understanding of IFRS and their implications for prudential reporting. Expected outputs include videoconferences and workshops for both the Financial Reporting and Audit and Oversight CoP(s), and support for their work through providing technical assistance, guidance and appropriate linkages with EU and relevant global peers. E)pected outputs also include the provision of training seminars in IFRS and prudential requirements for central banks and financial sector regulators in the Region, and the creation of an information e-portal that will enable the training and technical outputs t) be made available throughout the Region. Specific technical guidance that is relevant to the thematic areas addressed under this component will be developed and disseminated, such as a Guide to tie accounting and auditing aspects of the acquis communawtaire. The CFRR will also continue to encourage and facilitate 1he use of the CoP(s) to provide peer-learning case clinics for countries facing immediate specific challenges in financial reporting or auditing. (iv) Provide support for implementation of national CAPs through policy advice, supervision, and monitoring and evaluation of progress in implementation of individual CAPs. Expected outputs include effective policy advice and timely supervision of implementation; periodic Accounting and Auditing Reports on the Observance of Standards and Codes (A&A ROSC) updates; ilevelopment of performance indicators in the field of corporate financial reporting; development/documentation of best practices; and knowledge maintenance and dissemination. These activities will allow for defining the results agenda in the area of corporate financial reporting reform, for disseminating good practices, as well as for development of relevant and realistic performance indicators and benchmarks. (v) Management of MDTF Activities and MDTF Administration. Carry oul, through CFRR, (a) coordination and management of activities carried out under this MDTF, (b) management and administratior of the REPARIS secretariat and the Trust Fund, and (c) donor coordination.
ï»¿-9- (b) Recipient-Executed rrust Fund Activities: Impleme itation of Country Action Plans. Provide support to Beneficia-y Countries for implementation of their respective CAPs. iplementation of the CAPs will be carried out in phases, over the medium to long-term, supported by a detailed project design fo each phase. The Recipient-Executed activities will be based on a sttong reliance on country ownership and capacity, on one hand and on the transfer of the knowledge and experience acquired and exchanged in the context of regional activities with a view to Iacilitating the design and implementation of respective CAPs, on the other hand. Expected outputs. Implementation of the first phase of the CAPs, with the focus on priority activities for the corporate financial reporting in preparing foundations for implementation of the subsequent phases. Specifically, expected outputs will be (i) improving the legal framework; (ii) strengthening the national accounting standard setter; (iii) establishing a public oversight system f(r independent auditors; (iv) improving accounting and auditing curricula; and (v) strengthening reform capacity of the Governmnt in the area of corporate financial reporting to carry on implemertaticn of the subsequent phases as set out in respective CAPs. D. Categories of E.Denditures (a) For Bank-Executed activities the Contributions may be used to finance (i) Bank staff costs, (ii) consultants, (iii) temporary staff costs, extended-term consultants, (iv) field assignment benefits, (v) contractual services, (vi) media and workshop costs, (vii) travel expenses for Bank staff, short-term consultants, short-term temporary staff, extended-term consultants and extended-term temporary staff, and (viii) associated overheads. (b) For Recilient-Executed activities the Contributions may be used to finance (i) goods, (ii) consultants' services including audit, (iii) training, -nd (iv) operating costs. The foregoing categories of expenditures may include the financing of taxes.
ï»¿-10- E. Governance The governance structu-e for management of all corporate financial reporting reform programs in the ECA R.gion is also applied to the governance and management of tiis Trust Fund. (a) Strategic oversight, policy and institutional issues. The Donor Advisory Counc .1 (DAC) wh:.ch comprises of representatives of development partners will piovide strategic and policy guidance on institutional capacity strengthening in the field of corporate financial reporting, with reliance on spec fic and relevant thematic discussion papers and studies prepared by the CFRR. The DAC has the final responsibility (the CFRR carries out M&E and submits a report to the DAC for its appreciation) for monitcring and evaluation of progress of the reforms and may commission an independent p,-rformance audit. (b) MDTI' manage ment and implementation of its activities. The Bank manages and administers the REPARIS MDTF through the CFRR. The Bank shall prepare, review and approve the annual work plan and budget for actIvities carried out under the REPARIS MDTF. While the approval of annual work plan and budget of REPARIS rests with the Bank, the DAC members contrIbuting to REPARIS may provide comments on the proposed work p an and budget and these may be discussed with the Bank prior to the apprcval of annual work plan and budget. The CFRR decides the activities to be funded from the REPARIS MDTF in accordance with strategic guidance from DAC and the related demand from Beneficiary Countries, and taking into account recommendations of RLG and MPG and budget constraints. The CFRR reports to DAC on the progre:3s in implementation of the MDTF annual work plan. In the capacity of secretariat to the REPARIS MDTF, the CFRR will (a) assist he Beneficiary Countries in raising adequate funding to support implementation of their respective CAPs; (b) administer funds provided by development partrers in support of implementation of both the regional and country specific activities under the REPARIS MDTF; and (c) report on progress in implementation of all activities carried out under the REPARIS MDTF to both participating development partners and Beneficiary Countries. (c) Consultations on subject matters. (i) Regulatory Liaison Group. On the basis of periodic reports by the CFRL on the policy underpinnings for its analytical, advisory and implcmertation activities, the technical views of the RLG are sought or the alignment of this policy foundation with current and emerging best practice; on the coordination of relevant capacity
ï»¿-11- developrrent activities by RLG members with those of the Centre; and on the extent and sequencing of the adoption and implemer tation of EU and international best practice in the specific :ircLmstances of the CFRR's partner countries. The involveme-nt of these organizations in the RLG is also expected to facilitate the ability of the CFRR to mobilize their specific assistancc in t-e context of individual programs and projects. (ii) Market Participants Group. On the basis of structured consultations and periodic reports by the CFRR on what are considered to be the main areas of financial reporting in need of reform, the practical views of the MPG are sought on the key impedimnts to high quality financial reporting in the CFRR's partner countries, and on the extent of progress being achieved over timc. The involvement of these entities in the MPG is also expected to facilitate the raising of private sector funding to support the activities of the CFRR, and the ability of the CFRR to mobilize their specific assistance at country level in making the case for f nancial reporting reform.
